Limit law of a second class particle in TASEP with non-random initial condition

Abstract

We consider the totally asymmetric simple exclusion process (TASEP) with non-random initial condition and density Î»ğœ†\lambda on â„¤âˆ’subscriptâ„¤\mathbb{Z}_{-} and ÏğœŒ\rho on â„¤+subscriptâ„¤\mathbb{Z}_{+}, and a second class particle initially at the origin. For Î»<Ïğœ†ğœŒ\lambda<\rho, there is a shock and the second class particle moves with speed 1âˆ’Î»âˆ’Ï1ğœ†ğœŒ1-\lambda-\rho. For large time tğ‘¡t, we show that the position of the second class particle fluctuates on the t1/3superscriptğ‘¡13t^{1/3} scale and determine its limiting law. We also obtain the limiting distribution of the number of steps made by the second class particle until time tğ‘¡t.

1 Introduction and main result

The totally asymmetric simple exclusion process (TASEP) is one of the simplest non-reversible interacting particle systems on â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z} lattice. A TASEP particle configuration is described by the occupation variables {Î·j}jâˆˆâ„¤subscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—â„¤\{\eta_{j}\}_{j\in\mathbb{Z}} where Î·j=1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘—1\eta_{j}=1 means site jğ‘—j is occupied by a particle and Î·j=0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘—0\eta_{j}=0 means site jğ‘—j is empty. The TASEP dynamics are as follows. Particles jump one step to the right and are allowed to do so only if their right neighboring site is empty. Jumps are independent of each other and are performed after an exponential waiting time with mean 111, which starts from the time instant when the right neighbor site is empty.

More precisely, denoting by Î·âˆˆğ’®={0,1}â„¤ğœ‚ğ’®superscript01â„¤\eta\in{\cal S}=\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{Z}} a configuration, the infinitesimal generator of TASEP is given by the closure of the operator Lğ¿L

Since particles can not overtake each other, we can associate a labeling to them and denote the position of particle kğ‘˜k at time tğ‘¡t by xkâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘¡x_{k}(t). We choose the right-to-left ordering, namely, we have xk+1â€‹(0)<xkâ€‹(0)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜10subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜0x_{k+1}(0)<x_{k}(0) for any kğ‘˜k.

The observable we study in this paper is the so-called second class particle. The only difference between a particle described above (also called first class particle) with a second class particle is the following: when a first class particle tries to jump on a site occupied by a second class particle, the jump is not suppressed and the two particles interchanges their positions. Second class particles can be also seen as discrepancies between two TASEP systems coupled by the basic coupling, see e.g.Â [26], starting from p.218, for further details. For instance, consider two TASEP configurations Î·,Î·â€²âˆˆğ’®ğœ‚superscriptğœ‚â€²ğ’®\eta,\eta^{\prime}\in{\cal S} which at time 00 differ only at the site 00. Then under basic coupling the two configurations will differ only at one site for any time tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0, and we can define

Xt=âˆ‘xâˆˆâ„¤xâ€‹ğŸ™{Î·tâ€‹(x)â‰ Î·tâ€²â€‹(x)}.subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥â„¤ğ‘¥subscript1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğœ‚â€²ğ‘¡ğ‘¥X_{t}=\sum_{x\in\mathbb{Z}}x\mathbbm{1}_{\{\eta_{t}(x)\neq\eta^{\prime}_{t}(x)\}}. (1.2)

to be the position of the second class particle at time tğ‘¡t. From this perspective, the distribution of Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t} gives an information on the correlation between Î·jâ€‹(t)subscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘¡\eta_{j}(t) and Î·0â€‹(0)subscriptğœ‚00\eta_{0}(0). For the case of the stationary initial condition, where every site is independently occupied with probability Ï±italic-Ï±\varrho, the law of the second class particle is precisely proportional to Covâ€‹(Î·jâ€‹(t),Î·0â€‹(0))Covsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚00{\rm Cov}(\eta_{j}(t),\eta_{0}(0)), see e.g.Â [31].

Second class particle are also very useful when the interacting system generates shocks, which are discontinuities in the particle density. Indeed, the position of the shock can be identified with Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t}, see ChapterÂ 3 ofÂ [26]. For that reason already several studies are devoted to the second class particles. For instance, consider a single second class particle starting at the origin. For TASEP initial condition is Bernoulli product measure with density Î»ğœ†\lambda on â„¤âˆ’={â€¦,âˆ’3,âˆ’2,âˆ’1}subscriptâ„¤â€¦321\mathbb{Z}_{-}=\{\ldots,-3,-2,-1\} and density ÏğœŒ\rho on â„¤+={1,2,3,â€¦}subscriptâ„¤123â€¦\mathbb{Z}_{+}=\{1,2,3,\ldots\} with Î»<Ïğœ†ğœŒ\lambda<\rho. Then Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t} moves with an average speed of 1âˆ’Ïâˆ’Î»1ğœŒğœ†1-\rho-\lambda and it has Gaussian fluctuations on a t1/2superscriptğ‘¡12t^{1/2} scaleÂ [9, 10, 22, 12]. For shocks created by deterministic initial data,Â [17] obtained the limit law of a first class particle located at the shock. Later, multipoint distributions of several particles at the shock where obtainedÂ [18], and the transition to shock fluctuations was studiedÂ [28]. For the case Î»<Ïğœ†ğœŒ\lambda<\rho, what remained open is the limit law of the second class particle Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t}, and this is what we obtain in this paper.

When the initial condition is product Bernoulli measure with Î»ğœ†\lambda on â„¤âˆ’subscriptâ„¤\mathbb{Z}_{-} and ÏğœŒ\rho on â„¤+subscriptâ„¤\mathbb{Z}_{+} with Î»>Ïğœ†ğœŒ\lambda>\rho, a second class particle placed initially at the origin chooses one direction uniformly among its characteristics and then moves at a constant speed along that directionÂ [11, 27]. This means that the fluctuations of the second class particle are of order tğ‘¡t. Tightly related with the trajectory of the second class particle is the notion of competition interface in a last passage percolation model introduced inÂ [13] for Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 and Ï=0ğœŒ0\rho=0. This connection was later extended for more general cases inÂ [12]. They prove that for any initial conditions with asymptotically density Î»<Ïğœ†ğœŒ\lambda<\rho to the left and right of the origin respectively, a second class particle moves along a characteristics, chosen according to a random distribution which depends on the initial condition. However only for the Bernoulli initial condition is the precise distribution known.

For constant density results on the fluctuations of the second class particle are known only for the stationary case. Using coupling arguments it was shown inÂ [5] that the fluctuation scale of the second class particle is t2/3superscriptğ‘¡23t^{2/3} (by controlling some moments). The exact limiting distribution has been obtained inÂ [20].

One aspect of TheoremÂ 1.1 is the form of the limiting distribution. It is a linear combination of two independent random variables. This is directly related to the fact that the shock is the location where two characteristic lines meet. Secondly, the t1/3superscriptğ‘¡13t^{1/3} scale is indirectly related with the fact that TASEP is in the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) universality classÂ [24] in 1+1111+1 dimensions (see surveys and lecture notesÂ [21, 7, 33, 4, 32, 16]). Finally the GOE Tracy-Widom distribution is due to fact that the regions from where the two characteristic lines starts are have fixed densities and they are non-random (such situations are called flat initial conditions for KPZ modelsÂ [30, 14], see PropositionÂ 3.1).

Further, TheoremÂ 1.1 indeed shows that that the t1/2superscriptğ‘¡12t^{1/2} fluctuation of Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t} (and the Gaussian distribution) observed with Bernoulli-Bernoulli initial condition strongly depends on the randomness of the initial condition. The reason is that the fluctuations generated by the dynamics (of KPZ type) are not visible as they are much smaller than the Gaussian fluctuations of the initial condition of the two regions which are strongly correlated with the shock. Finally, notice that when Î»âˆ’Ïâ†’0â†’ğœ†ğœŒ0\lambda-\rho\to 0, the constant Î¥Î¥\Upsilon in (1.7) converges to 00. This is not surprising as a similar phenomenon has been observed for the random initial condition, Î»âˆ’Ïâ†’0â†’ğœ†ğœŒ0\lambda-\rho\to 0 corresponds to look at the stationary initial condition, where the position of the second class particle has a non-trivial limiting distribution in the t2/3superscriptğ‘¡23t^{2/3} scaleÂ [20, 31].

On the way to TheoremÂ 1.1, we determine a technical result which, however, has its own interest. In LemmaÂ 3.6 we find a Gaussian bound for the tail of the distribution of the starting point (or, exit point) of a geodesic in the stationary model of last passage percolation (defined in (3.41)) from a line to a point.

Method and outline

The result of the paper uses as first ingredient the asymptotic independence of the last passage times from two disjoint initial set of points of a last passage percolation (LPP) modelÂ [17], see PropositionÂ 3.1, which is a consequence of slow-decorrelationÂ [15, 8]. The trajectory of the second class particle is the same as the competition interface in LPP introduced by Ferrari and Pimentel inÂ [13]. It is however not straightforward to extend the result on the competition interface of Ferrari and Nejjar, TheoremÂ 2.1 ofÂ [18], to the position of the second class particle. The reason being that between the two observables there is a random time change and the second class particle moves with non-zero speed.

The next key ingredient in the proof is a tightness-type result on the two LPP problems, see PropositionÂ 3.2 and CorollaryÂ 3.4. This extends to general densities the method of PimentelÂ [29], which extends the comparison with the stationary process by Cator and PimentelÂ [6], see LemmaÂ 3.5. For its application one has to estimate the tail probabilities of the exit points, see LemmaÂ 3.6 and LemmaÂ 3.8. The latter as well as the limiting GOE Tracy-Widom distributions are taken from the recent universality result for flat initial condition by Ferrari and OccelliÂ [19].

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2 we recall the connection between TASEP and LPP as well between second class particle and competition interface. We then collect asymptotic result on LPP which are used later. SectionÂ 3.2 contains the proof of TheoremÂ 1.1. It is based of preliminary results on the control of LPP at different points, whose proof is presented after the one of the main theorem.

2 Some results on TASEP and LPP

Here we first recall the connection between TASEP and LPP, then between the second class particle and the competition interface, and finally we collect some known result about LPP.

3 Proof of the main theorem

In SectionÂ 3.1 we provide some results on the limiting LPP problems as well as tightness-type results. The proofs are mostly postponed to SectionÂ 3.3. These results are then employed to prove the main result, TheoremÂ 1.1 in SectionÂ 3.2.

Lemma 3.5.

Fix some 0<x1<x20subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥20<x_{1}<x_{2}. Now, whenever Zstat,Ï±â€‹(x1)â‰¤ZÎ»â€‹(x2)superscriptğ‘statitalic-Ï±subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥2Z^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(x_{1})\leq Z_{\lambda}(x_{2}), then we get

In contrast, when ZÎ»â€‹(x1)â‰¤Zstat,Ï±â€‹(x2)subscriptğ‘ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘statitalic-Ï±subscriptğ‘¥2Z_{\lambda}(x_{1})\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(x_{2}) holds, then we have

Proof.

One can find similar result in LemmaÂ 1 ofÂ [6] for the exit point in Hammerseley process. Furthermore,Â [29] it has been generalized in the case of line to point last passage percolation with any two initial profiles along the anti-diagonal. Our proof closely follows the arguments of LemmaÂ 2.1 ofÂ [29]. We prove in detail only (3.49) since the proof of (3.50) is similar.
